qas.question: How many main viewpoints divide many philosophers?
The realist view states that time is part of the fundamental structure of what?
The realist view is sometimes referred to as what?
The opposing view states that time is an intellectual concept that allows people to what?
How many viewpoints are there about different dimensions?
Gottfried Leibniz believed time is part of the fundamental structure of what?
What does the realist view believe don't exist of themselves?
What did Sir Isaac Newton believe time and space were the product of?
What did Sir Isaac Newton believe was the only way we can know objects?
How many main viewpoints divide many sequences?
Who subscribed to the third view?
What is another name for the second view?

plausible_answers.text: that space and time "do not exist in and of themselves

qas.question: What does the third view hold that?
Who believe in the third view?

context: <a0_0><b4_0><b9_0>Two<b9_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> distinct viewpoints on time divide many prominent philosophers. One view is that time is part of the fundamental structure of <a1_0><b5_0>the universe<b5_0/><a1_0/>, a dimension in which events occur in sequence. <b10_0>Sir Isaac Newton<b10_0/> subscribed to this realist view, and hence it is sometimes referred to as <a2_0><b11_0>Newtonian time<b11_0/><a2_0/>. An opposing view is that time does not refer to any kind of actually existing dimension that events and objects "move through", nor to any entity that "flows", but that it is instead an intellectual concept (together with space and number) that enables humans <a3_0>to sequence and compare events<a3_0/>. This second view, in the tradition of <b13_0>Gottfried Leibniz and Immanuel Kant<b13_0/>, holds <b12_0>that <b6_0>space and time<b6_0/> "do not exist in and of themselves<b12_0/>, but ... are the product of <b7_0>the way we represent things<b7_0/>", because we can know objects only <b8_0>as they appear to us<b8_0/>.
